title: Repository of SPO Testing Resources
description: Small pool operators do not have a central place where they can find tools and information to test their stake pool.

f6_assessments.q0: Yes, a repository would support SPO to extend necessary knowledge about existing and new protocols. The proposal does not provide a lot of information
f6_assessments.q1: The proposal itself does not provide sufficient information, but since the proposed goal is so clear it is still very likely that the team will be able to complete their task. There is no information about any cooperations or partnerships within the community or the SPOs provided so it is not clear if the proposers already have insights into which repositories, tools and measurements are already implemented and would be documented.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal does not provide a detailed roadmap or timeline or any step by step actionable overview on how the team intends to gather information and achieve outreach and most importantly, ensure visibility for their proposed website. If a website is used to provide relevant information, the team should include some information on how they intend to reach out to SPOs so that they will be able to know where to find the repository. Definition of success (3/6/9/12) is not included.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal is aligned with the Challenge since it addresses a limitation regarding SPOs testing and discussion resources. Although, it's not possible to effectively know about its impact since the idea is only brief and was not detailed, for e.g., with more information about such a platform/repository, why this proposal is important, i.e., what motivated the proposing team. The problem statement briefly mentions that, but it's not possible to really understand the problems without being a SPO, at least. Some metrics should be added into the proposal as well in order to compare it with the Challenge's metrics to check proposal alignment with it. Also, the proposal could mention how it expects to sustain itself after this first work is finished to make it sustainable. Score: 1
f6_assessments.q1: The proposer mentions an aggregated 40 years of experience with IT, which means that there is a team behind the project, but it does not provide more information about it, like how many people will work on it, who are the team members and some relevant links to check their background. The proposer sets the proposal goals, but it does not mention how it would be implemented, i.e., there is no road map with the details about each step, timeline and milestones to understand when some partial results would be delivered, and what effort they would take. Also the budget is not well explained, and it seems to be low compared to what is proposed, since considering an average cost of $50/h, it would pay for 22h summing up all team members, and it does not seem possible to build such a platform with this amount of money. Score: 1
f6_assessments.q2: The auditability of this proposal could be improved if the proposer had provided more information like a structured roadmap with deadlines, milestones, partial deliverables, and also some metrics and KPIs for the community to properly follow up. The way the proposal is now, it's not possible to keep track of the progress being done, what is the goal of auditability here. Also, the budget is presented as a lump sum only, which doesn't help with keeping track of the expenses during the project execution. This information should be added in order to improve the proposal's auditability. Score: 1

f6_assessments.q0:
While I'm not an SPO myself, I've been staking my ADA since October 2020 and being an active member of the community recently, I understand the need to have resources available for current or aspiring SPO's. I've also been delivering software as a QA engineer for 7 years, so I have experience with planning and executing projects.
I think the problem statement is very clear and well formulated. To me, it's also placed in the right challenge, as it aims to improve the security of the network by empowering SPO's. I completely agree that they should have documentation available to help them set up their stake pools and test them properly. The solution and implementation plan also sound clear to me, although I think they can be improved with a few more details. For example, what is the plan for fostering discussions on the SPO topic? To make the proposal more robust, I think something like a weekly workshop for this could be suggested. Other options might include surveys sent out to SPO's to gather data.
Next, I love the idea of having a website dedicated for this, or a section of an existing website. However, I feel like this must be figured out before the proposal can be funded, as it's central to the success of its implementation. Likewise, metrics of success and KPI's should also be identified before the proposal can be funded (maybe poll SPO's on how much they test their stake pools now and then again after the documentation has been aggregated and they had a chance to act on it).
Due to the above mentioned reasons, for now I have to disagree that the proposal effectively addresses the challenge, but I must outline that I love this idea and I hope that the proposers will come back to it and improve it. I would like to see this happen.
f6_assessments.q1:
Unfortunately, I do not think it is highly likely for the proposal to be implemented successfully, as lots of critical information is missing from it. I will present my suggestions on how the proposal can be improved below:
- The proposers should add their credentials (LinkedIn, Github repositories etc) in order to raise the trustworthiness of the proposal and make it more likely to attract votes
- The proposers should clearly outline what type of people are needed in order to make this happen and how they will enlist them. For example: Designer, UI dev, backend dev, QA, project manager (which would also facilitate workshops, if they were to be held) etc
- The objective should be broken down into specific tasks and then the tasks should be estimated (time & money). For example: Design - 8h, $20/h, $160 total. The currently outlined budget is more than reasonable in my opinion, it just needs to be more detailed (also consider adding in an extra for contingency).
- A timetable of what needs to be done and when should also be provided. It's very important to have an estimate of when the work will start, when it will end and when it is expected to have the site operational.
- Another plus would be to identify and briefly describe the technical approach to building the website, for even more transparency (for example, mentioning the framework that would be used for the UI, how data will be fed into the site etc)
- I would also like to hear a long term plan on who will maintain the site and update it with new information, after the initial implementation. What resources they need for this, if the community would be somehow involved etc.
- Lastly, it would be worth dedicating a section to identifying what problems / risks could be encountered while trying to implement this and what the approach to solving would be.
f6_assessments.q2: I do not think the information currently present in the proposal is enough to audit the progress of the proposal, since no metrics for success are defined, there are no KPI's mentioned and there is no clear roadmap to getting this done. However, it looks to me like the proposers identified a very valid problem in the ecosystem and also have a good solution to it. As mentioned earlier, I hope you will come back to this (assuming the project does not get funded this round) and we will see it being done eventually. Good luck!

f6_assessments.q0: This concise proposal effectively addresses the challenge of how to help stake pool operators by creating an active repository of resources/tools. SPOs are the heartbeat of the Cardano Ecosystem and are critical to maintaining a truly decentralized platform. Smaller SPOs are key to decentralization and growth in small SPOs is also key. They might not have the resources or expertise of the larger operators so this repository will help keep Cardano decentralized.
f6_assessments.q1: The teams 40 years of experience in IT, system administration, operating servers in production environments is impressive and gives me confidence in their ability to implement this proposal successfully.
f6_assessments.q2: There is no detailed breakdown of 3 month, 6 month, and one year goals. It is difficult for anyone to audit the progress of the proposal without knowing the timeline. The budget is very reasonable though and so success can be measured my completion of stated goal "a central webpage with links to existing tools and documentation".

solution: Create a repository for resources and discussion regarding SPO testing, catalog existing test tools, create discussion areas.
experience: Aggregate of 40 years IT, system administration, operating servers in production environments
